data.name: ES5 Generators(ii)
data.description:
This is the second part of three ([part1](http://www.codewars.com/kata/es5-generators-i), [part3](http://www.codewars.com/kata/es5-generators-iii)).

Given the implementation of this functions (they are preloaded and it is not necessary to implement them):

```javascript
//generator
function generator(sequencer) {
   ...
}

//sequencers
function factorialSeq() {...} // 1, 1, 2, 6, 24, ...
function fibonacciSeq() {...} // 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 12, ...
function rangeSeq(start, step) {...} // rangeSeq(1, 2)  -> 1, 3, 5, 7, ...
function primeSeq() {...} // 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, ...
partialSumSeq(1, 3, 7, 2, 0) {...} // 1, 4, 11, 13, 13, end
```

Using in this way:

```javascript
var seq = generator(factorialSeq);
seq.next(); // !0 = 1
seq.next(); // !1 = 1
seq.next(); // !2 = 2
seq.next(); // !3 = 6
seq.next(); // !4 = 24
...
```

You have to implement the `pipeSeq()` function. This function allows you to pipe generator to some functions. Thus the generated sequence is streamed to a function.

`pipeSeq()` receives the sequencer function and optionally some parameters passed to the sequencer and returns and object with two methods:

* `pipeline(pipe)` :receives the pipe function and optionally some parameters passed to the pipe function. It returns itself.
* `invoke()`: return the piped sequencer object.

This is and example to understand this:

Given this pipeline function:

```javascript
function accumulator() {
  var sum = 0;
  return function(value) {
    sum += value;
    return sum;
  };
}

//Example
var ac = accumulator(); // ac(1) -> 1, ac(4) -> 5, ac(2) -> 7
```

We could create the piped sequencer like this:

```javascript
var pipedSeq = pipeSeq(rangeSeq, 2, 3) // 2, 5, 8, 11
      .pipeline(accumulator) // 2, 7 (5+2), 15(7+8), 26(15+11)
      .invoke();
```

`pipedSeq` is a range sequencer whose values are streamed to the `accumulator()` function. This function sum the values of the sequence.

These are the expected results:

```javascript
var seq = generator(pipedSeq);
seq.next(); // 2
seq.next(); // 7
seq.next(); // 15
seq.next(); // 26
...
```
The same `pipedSeq` object can have more than one pipe.

You sould implement too the `isEven` pipe function:

```javascript
function isEven(){...}

var ie = isEven(); // ie(1) -> {status: false, number:1}, ie(4) -> {status: true, number:4}
```

Good Luck!
